events.target_title: Artifacts in filters when aux input depends on filter result

note.body:
When checking "Split view" and changing a parameter, I get a weird line in the middle corresponding to where the divisor line in the split view was. I guess that's part of the same issue?

Also, unchecking "Aux Input" causes the plugin to have no effect for me, therefore the checkbox seems meaningless. I would have expected that the same layer I'm going to apply the effect on is used as input, at least when the checkbox is unchecked.

events.target_title: Artifacts in filters when aux input depends on filter result

note.body:
My comment applies to 2.10 as of May 30 (476742b), with a few minor patches to get it to compile with older glib/gtk, which I suppose are not relevant to this report.

As a user, I would expect that when the aux input is not selected, it uses as input the same layer to which the effect is going to be applied, rather than the filter doing nothing. "Aux" suggests "not main".

As for the line, here is a complete list of steps to reproduce:

a) Image generation (or use the attached)

a1. Create a new image.  
a2. Apply "Hurl" to 100% and seed 1.  
a3. Blur to radius 15.  
a4. Stretch contrast.

![BumpMap-testimage](/uploads/2b4d28799a63eac7110c3934ef170bad/BumpMap-testimage.png)

b) Bump Map problems

b1. Open the Bump Map filter.

Problem 1: The filter doesn't use the destination layer as input for the effect. Aux Input has nothing, and checking/unchecking the checkbox does nothing.

b2. Select the same layer used as input.  
b3. Check "Split view" (Order of b3 and b4 is important)  
b4. Raise "Depth" to maximum (65).  
b5. Click OK.

Problem 2: A vertical line appears at the centre of the image:

![BumpMap-result](/uploads/6216b211116a644d1fbc94f501e2ac0e/BumpMap-result.png)

events.target_title: Artifacts in filters when aux input depends on filter result

note.body:
I guessed that the central line may be related to this comment by @tmanni:

> The issue happens when the filter is used on a layer and the image projection (containing that layer) is used as auxiliary buffer.

I might be wrong, though. I presumed that the issue is that the central line is included in the projection, and if the projection is used for any purpose, it will have a consequence in the result.

Edit: It's also possible that there's an off-by-one in the calculation of the preview extents. I'd take a look myself but I don't know where to look in the first place.

note.body: That doesn't make a difference in this case. As I said, it's the minimal script that reproduces the problem; in the original I create a layer, and it is also reproducible when `gimp-display-new` is called with a preexisting image with layers.

events.target_title: Script-Fu script causes error "Unable to run GimpPdbProgress callback"

note.body:
Despite the "Gimp-Python" label, this issue is NOT related to Python, as stated in the OP. I don't know if it's OS-specific. Maybe it is.

To recap:

- It doesn't happen unless the script opens a parameter entry dialog when called. This means that the script MUST be installed before running it. It can't be reproduced using the Script-Fu console alone.
- It doesn't happen unless the script creates a new display for an image, no matter if the image itself was created by the script or not.
- It doesn't happen unless the script shows a message at the end.
- It doesn't happen if the message is shown before creating the display.
- It doesn't happen in GIMP 2.8.18. It happens in GIMP 2.10.4.
- When it happens, the consequence is that an EXTRA message box appears, with the error message "Unable to run GimpPdbProgress callback. The corresponding plug-in may have crashed." *in addition to the one requested by the script.* The script seems to work otherwise. This message makes the plug-in look defective and therefore unreliable, even if it's not the case.

events.target_title: Script-Fu script causes error "Unable to run GimpPdbProgress callback"

note.body:
Update: This seems like a race condition. Adding this loop right before or right after showing the message makes the script finish without the extra error:

```scheme
(let ()
  (define x 0)
  (while (< x 100000)
    (set! x (+ x 1))))
```

YMMV. Setting the limit to 10,000 instead of 100,000 I got the message only sometimes. Regardless of the limit, the message is actually always shown after the loop finishes, even if the command to show it is before the loop. I guess that's normal.

@saifjsl The script works regardless of the message, you can safely ignore it. If that's not the case, we're not talking about the same bug.

events.target_title: Script-Fu script causes error "Unable to run GimpPdbProgress callback"

note.body:
A `git bisect` showed that this bug started happening at this commit:

```
b7dd2622d1ba206ba086e8cf08f6f1808fe5c32b is the first bad commit
commit b7dd2622d1ba206ba086e8cf08f6f1808fe5c32b
Author: Jehan <jehan@girinstud.io>
Date:   Wed Jun 7 15:27:33 2017 +0200

    Bug 774971 - Display errors outputted by GEGL.

    Add a log handler so that GIMP can display errors outputted by GEGL.
    Since third party code may run in threads and we have no control on
    these, we have to be sure GTK+ code is run in a thread-safe way, hence
    the usage of gdk_threads_add_idle_full(). This was the case here for
    GEGL, and handling GEGL logs the same way as other GIMP logs would
    result in crashes.
```

Not sure if that helps. It may be the case that this commit merely exposed the problem rather than causing it.

events.target_title: Script-Fu script causes error "Unable to run GimpPdbProgress callback"

note.body:
Sorry, I can't try with later versions to see if it's fixed. Maybe some years from now, when Debian includes 2.10 and I update, I can provide more information. All I can say is that it happened both in Linux and in a Windows virtual machine running in a Linux host.

The real script with which it happened is here:

http://wiki.secondlife.com/wiki/GIMP_Layers_to_SL_Animated_Texture

The script takes a series of layers and composes them in a single image, removing alpha when it's not necessary. I believe "Generate LSL script" had to be checked for the problem to show up.

Due to the nature of the problem, it's not unexpected that it works for some people depending on the speed of their machines.

events.target_title: UWP-ify GIMP

note.body:
I am in favour of having a UWP build. I have already installed [Inkscape](https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/9pd9bhglfc7h) and purchased [Krita](https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/9n6x57zgrw96). If there's a GIMP UWP build, even if it's paid to support the project, I'd get this one instead of the win32 build.

UWP apps offer so many advantages over win32 apps for the user, starting from auto-updates, which is really a killer feature. There's permission management, sandboxing, and the installation *and* uninstallation process are so much simpler and cleaner than legacy apps.

For developers, [this](/uploads/bde76d2391929d5a26a8ec47fef3ec4f/image.png) is a pain in the ass, but it's well worth it for the end-user and the other advantages for the publisher. One of them is [analytics](/uploads/b5f73d609405a2e3a6dc87129a916068/image.png), and there's also usage reports, health reports, ratings, reviews and feedbacks in one centralized place.

I guess you could also publish it on Steam since it acts just like a package manager would on Windows and consequently offers a few of the advantages the Windows Store offers. However, I prefer an Universal Windows Platform build.

To respond to **Michael Schumacher**, users of Windows 7 and above can upgrade using the [Media Creation Tool](https://www.microsoft.com/fr-ca/software-download/windows10).

events.target_title: Gnome software doesn't notify of new updates

note.body:
Okay I got some lead in this issue.
As I stated before, it happens only when the system is in aeroplane mode while login. So I decided to see the packagekit status using the command `pkmon`.


Here are some findings:
   * After login in, when the system is still in aeroplane mode, `pkmon` shows:

```  Transactions:
     [none]
     daemon connected=1
     network status=online 
```
I don't know how it was showing network status online even though my laptop was completely offline with aeroplane mode turned on.
   * Next I turned off aeroplane mode and my laptop automatically detects my home wifi and initiates connection to it. While it was still connecting, `pkmon` shows:
     
 ```
Transactions:
 1	/76_dccbeddb
/76_dccbeddb	allow_cancel 1
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   -1
/76_dccbeddb	role         get-updates
/76_dccbeddb	status       setup
/76_dccbeddb	status       query
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   3
/76_dccbeddb	status       loading-cache
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   8
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   13
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   18
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   23
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   28
/76_dccbeddb	percentage   33
/76_dccbeddb	status       download-repository
/76_dccbeddb	status       finished 
``` 
When my laptop finally established connection with the wifi network, `pkmon` did not show any other transactions.

Gnome software updates tab shows that my system is up to date with the `Last Checked` timestamp is the exact time when I booted up the system and wifi was in connecting mode. (Actually there were updates!)

Fedora comes with `dnf-makecache` systemd timer so I will test tomorrow if it shows any update notifications or not. Maybe it was getting updates metadata from the cache which was not yet updated but still, showing network status online even when the system is in aeroplane mode is alarming(possible packagekit bug).
Also checking package updates even if the connection was not `fully established` is a kind of possible bug.

My other machine which is a desktop and always online showing updates notifications fine.

events.target_title: Some little tips
Can't create new back buffer on Intel Atom

note.body: This issue has also been reported downstream in the Fedora Bugzilla: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1575194 . I am also affected on three different machines, one 32-bit, two 64-bit.

events.target_title: Can't create new back buffer on Intel Atom

note.body: As commented in the Fedora downstream bug, a workaround for this particular bug is to disable Wayland in /etc/gdm/custom.conf (WaylandEnable=false).

events.target_title: Can't create new back buffer on Intel Atom

note.body:
Also, in any affected machine, running "mutter --wayland" from the KMS system console (the one switched by Ctrl-Alt-Fn) also locks up in the same way, with the following messages:

>  
(mutter:5254): mutter-WARNING **: 16:10:15.305: failed to bind to @/tmp/.X11-unix/X0: Address already in use
>  
>  (mutter:5254): mutter-WARNING **: 16:10:15.305: failed to bind to @/tmp/.X11-unix/X1: Address already in use
>  glamor: EGL version 1.4 (DRI2):
>  Require OpenGL version 2.1 or later.
>  Failed to initialize glamor
>  Failed to initialize glamor, falling back to sw
>  
>  (mutter:5254): mutter-WARNING **: 16:10:15.933: Failed to create new back buffer handle: No such file or directory

The "Address already in use" could be disregarded as being caused by running GNOME under X11 in another console.

events.target_title: Can't create new back buffer on Intel Atom

note.body: @aklapper : According to https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1575194#c28 you need to check whether the "working" screen with gnome-shell 3.27.1-4.fc28 and mutter 3.27.1-4.fc28 is not actually the Xorg fallback. Have you checked for this?

events.target_title: Can't create new back buffer on Intel Atom

note.body: While running the "working" configuration, switch to a text console or otherwise start a shell. Then run "ps aux | grep Xwayland". If you see a Xwayland process, then the session is using Wayland. For confirmation, run "ps aux | grep Xorg", which should NOT show the Xorg process unless running in fallback Xorg mode.

Webkit backend is missing (Help not working, 'File/Open location' not working, 'File/Create/From webpage...' missing)

note.body:
@mitch i decided to look on the issue.

1. gio/glib itself allows to create extension to handle virtual file systems (GVFS). 
1. For windows such VFS is included to glib (see https://github.com/GNOME/glib/blob/master/gio/win32/gwinhttpvfs.c). For other systems developers expecting to use gvfs package, which allows to register filesystems using dbus and fuse dynamically.
1. I believe that gimp in fact using only local and http[s] virtual file systems, at least in the places like "open location" and help browser.
1. porting gvfs to osx is very time consuming effort and probably it will never work as expected due to very different architecture, missing dbus, etc.
1. writing small vfs module (e.g. curl based) seems to be a much easier thing. Giving the gimp [probably] using only http/https - that should be enough. Module could be distributed as dylib/so, gio supports plugins

TBH i also found a lot of reports in the net about broken gvfs also on linux. I think its not the best choice to use it for http/https instead of using curl directly.

events.target_title: GNOME 3.30.1 Menus not updating.

note.body:
@debee1jp In my case the problem happens in 2 abit different setups. Indeed I use the same laptop in both cases but then:

1. First setup is QHD screen in normal "landscape orientation" connected via Thunderbolt and then via DisplayPort.
2. The second setup is FHD screen connected via HDMI directly

If I close a laptop lid (and so only the one screen remains active) then menus start to behave properly. Once I open the lid menus are no longer updated.

So see it's not even needed to logout/reboot whatsoever.
Not sure how screen orientation really affects this situation as I would guess Gnome Shell doesn't care about orientation and picture transformation.

events.target_title: Deletion of UTF characters doesn't work properly
Deletion of UTF characters doesn't work properly
Should be possible to find all registered global shortcuts from the keyboard shortcuts dialog
Should be possible to find all registered global shortcuts from the keyboard shortcuts dialog

note.body:
Well, there is a difference between application specific shortcuts and global shortcuts. That Alt+leftarrow takes you back in the browser, I believe is perfectly fine to only have and find in the Browser application. However, what happened to me was that another application registered Alt+leftarrow as a global shortcut, causing the Browser in your case or Intellij in my case to never get the shortcut. This made the applications to not function properly. And when you have things that will affect other applications, they should be easy to find if you need to adjust them. 

So, to be clear, my request is only for global shortcuts.

events.target_title: Wrong time(zone?) in calendar events

note.body:
I see the exact same thing using gnome-calendar-3.32.2-5.fc30.x86_64 on Fedora 30. 
I added an event in Evolution against a CalDav backend, then opened Calendar and it is displayed two hours off. My timezone is CEST which is UTC+2 at the moment, which can be the explanation for 2 hours wrong.

events.target_title: Wrong time(zone?) in calendar events

events.target_title: Allow key bindings to paste PRIMARY selection

note.body:
This has always bugged me too.

Ages ago it used to work correctly: <kbd>Shift+Ins</kbd> would paste from PRIMARY, while <kbd>Ctrl+V</kbd> from CLIPBOARD, and it used to be consistent across widget libraries. 

Then, at some point, both combinations started pasting from CLIPBOARD in more and more UI toolkits (I don't understand why) and now there doesn't seem to be a way to paste from PRIMARY using the keyboard, except in terminal emulators or very old UI toolkits.

IMHO this needs to be at the very least a well-documented preference, if not reverted altogether.

note.body:
@aklapper In my experience, the poor performance issue is not uncommon, especially for the scanned pdf files, old journal articles and some presentations. These files are quite common in my daily life as a astrophysics student.

You may try this presentation(14.7MB):
http://ipta.phys.wvu.edu/files/student-week-2018/ryan_shannon_noise_ipta2018v2.pdf  
this journal article(1.7MB):
https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1982ApJ...255..419B/abstract  
or this one(444.3KB):
https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1985MNRAS.213..435K/abstract

There are many more these PDFs if you need, all rendering quit slow in my laptop, which is runing `evince 3.28.4` under `Ubuntu 18.04` with Intel i5 CPU.  
Reproduce of the issue is easy, just open the file. I don't know what more necessary information I can give.

I also encounter the performance issue with one PDF file output with beamer/latex myself, and I found the probelm is due one large inserted image(6.8M). After compressed the image(~886KB), the load time of the output PDF with `evince` become acceptable.  
While, with `mupdf` the performance is much better, even for the PDF file contain the large image without compressed, the file is opened almost instant, but it lack the basic UI to used as default PDF reader. 

I guess the performance issue of `evince` may relate to the image rendering. The scanned pdf files are just images. The presentations are also contain many images, some of which may quite large. For the old journal articles I have no ideas why.

btw have you consider about using `mupdf` as the backend of `evince`, or provide `mupdf` backend as an option.

events.target_title: Clarify multi-protocol nature of recent versions of openconnect

note.body:
> This is almost certainly wrong -- we shouldn't conditionalize this by the version, because the compile-time version might be just different than the runtime one.

Fair enough, but that's exactly what's done in `properties/nm-openconnect-editor-plugin.c`:

* If the (compile-time) API is <5.1, only AnyConnect is supported.
* If the (compile-time) API is [5.1, 5.4), AnyConnect and Juniper are supported.
* If the (compile-time) API is ≥5.5, the `openconnect_get_supported_protocols` is used.

… basically, if you build with an old version of `libopenconnect`, you're not gonna get multi-protocol support, even if you run with a newer version.

> Also, "Multi-protocol VPN client" is too universal. I don't really know would be better. The OpenConnect upstream seems to say it supports "SSL VPN" which might be good enough?

You can blame me for that description, which is now in the [upstream openconnect manpage](http://www.infradead.org/openconnect/manual.html).

```nroff
.TH OPENCONNECT 8
.SH NAME
openconnect \- Multi-protocol VPN client, for Cisco AnyConnect VPNs and others
…
.SH DESCRIPTION
The program
.B openconnect
connects to VPN servers which use standard TLS/SSL, DTLS, and ESP
protocols for data transport.
```

> Lastly, the upstream web makes it sound as if Juniper and Junos Pulse was actually the same thing? Perhaps just pick the more current name.

It's… confusing. @dwmw2 is the expert on the (reverse-engineered) Juniper protocol.

> In general, please avoid being too verbose there because it's not going to look good in the UI.

How about this?

```c
# define OPENCONNECT_PLUGIN_NAME    _("SSL VPN client (openconnect)")
# define OPENCONNECT_PLUGIN_DESC    _("Compatible with Cisco AnyConnect, Juniper, and PAN GlobalProtect SSL VPNs.")
```

events.target_title: Clarify multi-protocol nature of recent versions of openconnect

note.body:
The idea is that `openconnect` is no longer "just" a client for Cisco AnyConnect (and ocserv) VPNs. It support 3 protocols now, and all 3 have some kind of security trojan that the server can demand the client runs. `openconnect` supports this [anti]feature for all 3 protocols.

I'm trying to make the description here more generic so that if, say, a user is trying to configure NetworkManager to run a wrapper script for GlobalProtect HIP (CLI would be `openconnect --csd-wrapper hip-report.sh`), the user doesn't get confused by seeing an option that appears to apply to Cisco VPNs only.

The names of the API functions, internal variables, and command-line options (e.g. `--csd-wrapper`, `--csd-user`) are still rather Cisco-specific, but I see no reason why the GUI strings shouldn't be more generic.

> In case AVRCP is used then we do actually forward the key presses see:
>
> https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/bluetooth/bluez.git/tree/profiles/audio/avctp.c#n274

So I've enabled debug output on bluetoothd and from the only button that works I get:
```
profiles/audio/avctp.c:handle_panel_passthrough() AV/C: PLAY pressed
profiles/audio/avctp.c:handle_panel_passthrough() AV/C: PLAY released
```

which is correct. The other buttons generate no debug output. Taking a look at the code you mentioned in `handle_panel_passthrough` that's only possible if we ever early return via the `goto done` or the `return operand_count`.

I'd bet is some issue in the speaker implementation of avctp which is not strictly following the standard somehow. I'd say that we either hit https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/bluetooth/bluez.git/tree/profiles/audio/avctp.c#n388 or https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/bluetooth/bluez.git/tree/profiles/audio/avctp.c#n405

Thanks for your replies!

As a project manager myself I know that this needs someone in charge to bring it to life, but I have no idea how to handle that in the Gnome community (is it even possible without being in the "inner circle" to discuss and approve such feature issues?). I do have experience in leading software projects and are a member of the upcoming Ubuntu theme, but this is new to me.

Thanks a lot, 
Stefan

Function exported from ~/.profile not inherited
Function exported from ~/.profile not inherited

note.body:
Ok:

# To reproduce

1. Add this to ~/.profile:
    ```
    dummy_fun() { ls; }
    export -f dummy_fun
    export dummy_var=10
    ```

2. Create a desktop file with this in the Exec field: `bash -c set > /tmp/env`   
3. Restart your gnome session
4. Run your new desktop app from the gnome shell and check that both dummy_fun and dummy_var are in `/tmp/env`.
5. Remove `/tmp/env`.
6. Open nautilus and open some file using the new desktop app.
7. Check that dummy_var is in `/tmp/env` but dummy_fun isn't.

# Expected behavior

In step 7 above both dummy_var and dummy_fun should be in `/tmp/env`.

# Current behavior

Described in step 7 above.

---

What I assume is happening here is that the glib api for launching apps is not just letting the current environment pass to child processes as is but somehow taking a copy and explicitly setting the environment of the spawned processes. The exported functions could then be lost in the way since they are encoded in a bash specific manner.

events.target_title: Function exported from ~/.profile not inherited

note.body:
Notice this is not the problem since the rest of the environment is correctly inherited (that is the point of including the dummy_var sentinel in the steps above).

Also, exported functions are correctly inherited by other components of the gnome environment (that is the point of step 4 above).

So, to recap, the problem is that **exported functions** are not inherited **by nautilus**.

events.target_title: Function exported from ~/.profile not inherited

note.body: I mean, the problem might be related to the dbus daemon environment as you said, but the environment does include everything else in .profile, so the daemon must be inheriting it in some way that excludes functions.

events.target_title: Function exported from ~/.profile not inherited

note.body: The variable isn't there and I can't really set the value since it's a function... this is arcana, who knows how they're codified... See [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/26300455/2012920), at least at that moment the name of the function in the environment wasn't even a valid identifier. If that's so it's probably some component manipulating the environment and discarding what "doesn't parse".

note.body:
Ok, sorry for the delay. I can confirm that dummy_fun is in nautilus environment after exporting it and calling dbus-update-activation-environment as you said:

```
dummy_fun() { ls; }
export -f dummy_fun
dbus-update-activation-environment 'BASH_FUNC_dummy_fun%%'
```

note.body: Notice however that the name encoding is a bash implementation detail, if users start to rely on exported functions (not that it's such a popular feature in the desktop environment though ;) ) you risk being forced to discontinue support for this feature in a future.

note.body:
Thanks for the fast answer!
```
$ gio mount -a smb://192.168.122.201/share
gio: smb://192.168.122.201/share/: Accès anonyme refusé
```
"Anonymous access denied": this seems normal from what I understand, as I think I would have to enable guest account on the Windows 10 server for this to work (not tested). It also matches what I get with `mount.cifs`:
```
$ sudo mount.cifs //192.168.122.201/share /mnt -o guest
mount error(13): Permission denied
Refer to the mount.cifs(8) manual page (e.g. man mount.cifs)

note.body:
Hey @carlosg 

I did a little sysprof run for this case. My testing field looked like this:
![testing-ground](/uploads/f0b4a8d47fb70166053d2954657718df/testing-ground.png)

The amount of windows is so big just to make it very obvious in the results. Test with 2-3 windows is still very visible to my eye on 144Hz monitor tough...

Here is the sysprof file: [dragging-profile.syscap](/uploads/20a5f796682502e8f7de1774eaeca252/dragging-profile.syscap)

The starting period in that file is without me doing any dragging action.
![timeline](/uploads/39d8fc78911b436b5c8f77f353368829/timeline.png)
You can see that gnome-shell sits at about 34% from the rest of the system. After that quiet time I start dragging one terminal window around my testing field. Now you can see a spike in the system and if you slice out that section, you can see that gnome-shell is sitting at about 58% from the rest of the system during that intense system usage period. 
At least in my opinion it is a significant jump.

Please do let me know if the profile file opened nicely and what I provided was enough for you.

note.body:
> The shield.  And we currently have no way to disable it for our users.  The main complaint is that it is an unintuitive extra step to login.  Yes, you can type the password straight away, but there is no UI to indicate that this is so.  Heck, in the version of GNOME in RHEL7, there's not even any UI hint on how to remove the shield at all, or even what it is!

I completely agree that this lock screen shield is terrible, it should never have been set as default nor unconfigurable! Any argument against it is anti-user, this is fancy design over simple usability.

I do not want to open my laptop, have some annoying shield struggle to be displayed, swipe or press Esc and then enter my password. And do not say I can just enter my password because that is plain ridiculous without an input dialog showing, I mean as a user you have no idea if the all the password characters you have entered have been captured because there is no feedback.

If I wake up my laptop and have no lock then return me to my desktop, otherwise show a field to enter my password. My laptop sleeps after 5mins so I want to just open the lid and type my password in. The faster I can return to working on my laptop the better, it's that simple.

Anything less than offering a simple login experience is going to continue user frustration with using Gnome! Don't go by your hunches or what you think the community wants, actually determine what they need. For example:

> Whether we "blindly" accept a password has got nothing to do with the shield concept. It's actually the way that GNOME has always worked, since long before the current design, and is something that we have retained largely as a result of user pressure. It helps to reduce friction when unlocking, so it's surprising that you're requesting a change to this behavior.

This can be inferred as your users hating the meddling with the login screen and instead of wanting a way to quickly unlock their machines. So just give that to them by showing a password field.

I finally want to add that we have focused for years on speeding up the boot time of computers but the Gnome lock screen is going in the opposite direction and slowing down the resumption of a session.

New Nautilus behavior reads clipboard continuously, unexpectedly, security issue, breaks autocopy
New Nautilus behavior reads clipboard continuously, unexpectedly, security issue, breaks autocopy

note.body:
Sure, let me explain how I noticed and you can judge for yourself on the other points.

I use a password manager that has an autocopy feature, where it copies different text to the clipboard, in order, as you paste from the clipboard.  For example, if you tell it to copy your username to the clipboard, then paste it from the clipboard, it detects that you read what it put there and automatically copies your password into the clipboard so you can paste that, next.

Nautilus 3.30-2-stable breaks this feature of my other program.  I've seen this behavior before from other password managers that, presumably, are doing the same sort of thing and conflict.  But, they don't do it all the time.  Nautilus is constantly reading the clipboard *in a way that* causes my password manager to detect a read.  This *was not* happening with the previous version of nautilus (in Fedora 28, I don't know the exact version).  So, whatever changed with the way nautilus "continuously reads" the clipboard is ruining this other workflow for some applications.

Now, if it is reading the clipboard space in this way, then I conclude some more things:
1. It is doing it silently and unexpectedly.  There is no indication or reasons to expect it would read from the clipboard unless you told it to.
1. There is no way to turn off this behavior.
1. It is reading sensitive information that sometimes is present in the clipboard, however briefly, and that is a security issue.

Does that explain it better?

FYI, this issue has actually gotten worse.  The password manager that I use made a change to it's code to try to prevent this problem without changing Nautilus.  This worked, briefly.  Now, even that work around is broken.

Please fix this security issue.  Nautilus is accessing the clipboard without reason and reading passwords that are only there for a few seconds.

events.target_title: Keep overview open when  clicking the middle mouse button on dash icons

note.body:
Ok, I got wrong that middle-click already opens a new window. I'm not asking to change that, because middle clicking a not yet opened program currently does the same thing as left clicking it, right? So my request is basically just to also keep the overview open when middle clicking, just like with ctrl + left click.

For example, after booting I tend to open 2-3 programs from my dash. But I need to hold the ctrl key or the overview closes and I have to bring it up again, making the process more annoying than it has to be.

So making the middle click behave like ctrl+left click would fix that. I don't think it's a disruptive change. Surprising? Probably, on the 1st try. Confusing? Not really. You see exactly what happens. You just need to click on the window that just opened.

events.target_title: Ability to search in Nautilus and sort the results by column

note.body:
> So you would need sorting through the whole filesystem right?

Not exactly sure what you mean. Right now I'm looking for the biggest video files on a NAS for which I can't remember the name (auto generated nonsense), which is basically impossible with Nautilus.

At least you  can currently already search for "*" and it'll just list all sub-folder contents, which works surprisingly fast over here (on a Samsung 850 Evo SSD; doesn't let me do it over ethernet). Ideally, you could then sort that search result by columns, but a size filter would do for me for now.

In general, I think it wouldn't hurt if you could somehow (even if it's just accessible through dconf) enable actions that may be detrimental to performance. Depending on one's PC hardware, it might just work anyway.
